column9: 865616: How does multiple OLS regression enhance the understanding of relationships between variables and support causal inference in social science research, considering the concepts discussed in earlier lectures?
column11:
865617: First of all, please read and inspect the dataset.
As mentioned, it contains 2.771 responses from citizens in Copenhagen.
The most frequent highest level of education (Uddannelse) in the data is [edu]
The mean age (alder) in the data is [age]
column13:
865618: Plot the income variable.
The variable is based on a self.reported survey measure of household income. The variable has been made numeric by taking the mid-point of each income interval from the original survey question. If you want to, you can find the original survey here: https://www.kk.dk/sites/default/files/2023-06/Sp%C3%B8rgeskema%202023_0.pdf
If you could, how would you change the categories of the income-question in the survey?
column15:
865619: Calculate a regression model to inspect how income varies between educational-levels. Data is clustered on the Bydel-variable, so use the *clusters*-argument from the lm_robust-function.
Compared to respondents with 1.-10. klasse as their highest level of education, people with Lange videregående uddannelser on average has a household income [LVU]
Compared to respondents with 1.-10. klasse as their highest level of education, people with Gymnasial uddannelse on average has a household income [gym]
column17:
865620: It seems weird that persons with a higher level of education (Gymnasie) earns less than persons with a lower level of education (1. to 10. klasse).
An explanation could be that the age of the person is a confounder: Lenght of educations increase over generations. This means that older respondents on average have shorter educations than younger respondents. On average, grown ups tend to earn more than younger people! So lets see what happens when controlling for age.
When the model is controlled for age...
column19:
865621: So the relationship was not confounded by age... however, age can help explain the relationship between Gymnasieuddannelse and Indkomst in another way - namely as an interaction term.
Calculate an interaction model where Indkomst is explained by Uddannelse, alder, and an interaction term between the two predictors.
Please interpret the interaction and explain how the coeffiecient of Gymnasial uddannelse varies with alder:
column21:
865622: A problem with the model above is that the coefficient for *UddannelseGymnasial uddannelse* (or any of the Uddannelses-coefficients for that matter) is not very informative, as it communicates the uddannelses-coefficientes for age-values of 0 years... therefore, it is always informative to plot interaction models and especially to do so for the values of age actually occuring in the data set!
Use the ?-command to see the documentation from the plot_slopes-function from the marginaleffects-package in r. Now use the plot_slopes-function to visualize the interaction model.
Specify the *variables*-argument to "Uddannelse" and the *condition*-argument to "alder".
Please explain how age and education seems to be interacting when explaining income. Focus on Gymnasial uddannelse, but feel free to broaden the analysis.
column23:
865623: But wait - now we have included age as a first order term in our linear model. This does not have to be the case: As you saw in week 12, the functional form of the relationship between age and immigrant attitudes were better described by a polynomial model.
Now, use what you learned last week to plot the relationship between age and income as a linear model, a model with a quadratic term and a model with a cubic term.
Which of the three functional forms fit the data best?
column25:
865624: Now, calculate a model explaining Indkomst wit alder and a quadratic term of alder.
Interpret the model results:
The coefficient for alder is [alder]
The coefficient for alder^2 is [alder2]
This means, that the effect of age on income is [inter]
column27:
865625: Interpreting polynomial regressions is super hard!
Therefore, it is easier to visualize the results. The model that we just calculated can be used to interpret relationships between the independent and dependent variable - but it can also be used to predict values of the dependent variable based on values on the independent variable.
Use the fucntion "predictions" from the marginaleffects-package on the polynomial model from the question before. This gives as dataset where every row has a predicted income (estimate) based on their age. Now plot age (Alder) and the predicted income (estimate) with a point-plot.
At what age does the positive relationship between age and income seem to turn into a negative one?

column9:
Multiple Ols lets us investigate several explanatory variables in one model, it helps us see how one variable affects an outcome AFTER we've considered the effects of other variables. This reduces the risk that our results are biased by something we might have forgotten to include. This paints a clearer picture; we're controlling for other factors to see which relationships might be real and which relationships are coincidences; correlation doesn't mean causation.

By looking at not just two variables we can get closer to the ethereal goal of a causal prediction. But only closer! - multiple OLS regression doesn't prove cause and effect on it's own, but it takes us a step further to predicting some causality, at least further than simple correlations. So it works as an argument builder; for why certain things are linked, our conclusions might not be complete, but they're at least more informed.

Age and predicted log-income have a positive relationship. As age increases, income also increases "duh", but the strength and starting point of course differ from education level. 

Gymnasium: The predicted log- income for individuals with this education starts lower compared to the other education groups, the slope is still positive, indicating that income still increases with age. I would assume that the jobs that this education can give you is limited, gymnasium really only affects your opportunities for further education, but as age increases most people will have more experience working in what-ever fields they got a job in, so this will explain why their income grows over time. 

Comparing this to higher education the income starts higher, they're really substantial early in life and increase steadily with age. The slope is gradual, and remains positive. The people with "en gymnasiel uddannelse" income grows more with age, this could indicate that life experience can have a large effect on income if you're less educated. The medium long educations shows a middle ground between the two, while the "other" category remains flat, the pay stays pretty much the same during the lifecourse.

column9: OLS multiple regression provides insight into relationships between variables by isolating the specific effect of each independent variable while controlling for confounding factors. It reduces omitted variable bias and improves the precision of estimates. It also helps test nonlinear relationships and analyze mediation. Multiple OLS is an essential basis for analyzing social data and interpreting the effects of variables in complex contexts.

column21: The model shows that the effect of age on income varies with educational level. For individuals with a Gymnasial uddannelse, income starts with a significant disadvantage compared to the reference group, but this gap decreases with age, with their income increasing relatively faster. In contrast, individuals with higher levels of education (such as Mellemlange or Lange videregående uddannelser) have higher initial incomes that continue to increase significantly with age. Shorter or vocational education (such as Elevuddannelser) show relatively stable incomes with little age-related progression.

column9:
Multiple OLS regression enhances the understanding of relationships between variables and supports causal inference in social science research by allowing for the inclusion of multiple independent variables in the analysis. This helps control for confounders, which are factors that might otherwise bias the results by influencing both the dependent and independent variables. By including these additional variables in the model, multiple OLS regression can isolate the unique effect of each factor on the outcome, leading to a more accurate understanding of causal relationships.

Moreover, multiple regression provides insight into conditional relationships by showing how the effect of one variable on the outcome changes when holding other factors constant. This allows researchers to better capture the complexity of real-world social dynamics, making it a powerful tool for identifying and understanding causal mechanisms.

- Accounts for Multiple Predictors
- Controls for Confounding or mediator Variables

- Reducing Variable Bias

- Can find plausible mechanisms.

column21:
At around 50 years old one with "only" a gymnasial uddannelse will now earn as much on average as an individual with "only" folkeskolen as their longest education on average. This is due to the positive slope we see.

Alle the slopes in the graphs are positive, but with different intercepts (of course). 

A lot of them starts under zero (average income for somebody with only folkeskole) but crosses this line at some point. This could be due to the fact that while they are studying they don't earn so much money as the one with only folkeskole because they have the time to have a job. This job might be low-income but it is more than SU for example. this is also why it quickly shifts around 25 and 30 years old on average.

column13:
Der skal være flere kategorier til de rigeste, så mulighederne ikke stopper ved 1.000.000. Det kommer til at ligne at alle tjener ekstremt meget. 

 

 

In the plot, the x-axis has very bad values that are tricky to interpret. So the categories should follow the categories from the survey being: 

(_1) 0-99.000 kr.  (_2) 100.000-199.000 kr.  (_3) 200.000-299.000 kr.  (_4) 300.000-399.000 kr.  (_5) 400.000-499.000 kr.  (_6) 500.000-599.000 kr.  (_7) 600.000-699.000 kr.  (_8) 700.000-799.000 kr.  (_9) 800.000-899.000 kr.  (_10) 900.000-999.000 kr.  (_11) 1.000.000 kr. og derover  (_12) Vil ikke svare

 

Additionally, the question only measures the income, without other economic factors such as formue, opsparinger og evt. penge i hus/hjem.

column13: I'm not sure I understand the question. You're asking about the categories you're able to choose between in the survey? If so, I would have larger intervals the higher the income is. column21: First off all, across the different educations the level of education seem to influence income differently at different ages. But for the gymnasial uddannelse, there is a positive correlation between age and income. When the respondents are 25 years old they on average make 250.000 kroner less than a person with 1. to 10. klasse, but when the respondents are 50 years old, they on average have the same income as persons with 1. to 10. klasse education. Across the different types of educations, there is a positive correlation between age and income.

column21:
There is a very clear trend in the interaction: an increase in age leads to an increase in income. For gymnasial uddannelse, all ages below 50 have on average a lower income than the intercept (1-10. klasse). However, above the age of 50, the income is greater than the intercept. It is quite linear, with a wider confidence interval in the higher ages.

The positive trend is also seen in all the other categories. For elevuddannelser, the confidence interval is quite large. Only lange videregående uddannelser has a clearly higher income than 1-10. klasse, disregarding age.
